div.p: [With few exceptionsTanselle reminds us that “five of his Civil War poems were published in Harper’s between February and July 1866 (“The March to the Sea” in February, “The Cumberland” in March, “Philip”—later entitled “Sheridan at Cedar Creek”—in April, “Chattanooga” in June, and “Gettysburg” in July)” (NN PP 531)., the PiecesTitle, Battle-Pieces, "derived from his interest in the visual arts, since it was the standard term for battle scenes, especially nautical, as depicted in paintings and engravings." (Parker, II, 561) [Allusion, artistic; Source] (Marr) in this volume originated in an impulse imparted by the fall of Richmond. They were composed without reference to collective arrangement, but, being brought together in review, naturally fall into the order assumed.

The events and incidents of the conflict --- making up a whole, in varied amplitude, corresponding with the geographical area covered by the war --- from these but a few themes have been taken, such as for any cause chanced to imprint themselves upon the mind.

The aspects which the strife as a memory assumes are as manifold as are the moods of involuntary meditation---moods variable, and at times widely at variance. Yielding instinctively, one after another, to feelings not inspired from any one source exclusively, and unmindful, without purposing to be, of consistency, I seem, in most of these verses, to have but placed a harp[Allusion: Literary] Here Melville makes a clear allusion to lines 13-15 in “The Eolian Harp,” by Samuel Taylor Coleridge: “And that simplest Lute, / Placed length-ways in the clasping casement, hark! / How by the desultory breeze caressed,” in a window, and noted the contrasted airs[Poetics] Here Melville alludes to the numerous speakers and subjects within his poems, as well as to the highly varied form of his verse. Cohen tells us that “there are poems deal [sic] with officers of the highest rank and with enlisted men of both armies, with Negroes and whites, with civilians as well as soldiers, and with both men and women.” Cohen also notes “the remarkable range of verse forms [in Battle-Pieces], none of which is used more than once…” (19). which wayward winds have played upon the strings.]
